channel.title: My News Feed
channel.description: Recent content on My News Feed

item.title: Doorstep Circus comes to Knowle West
item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Doorstep Circus comes to Knowle West<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: ‘Let them kick the crap out of the songs’: how we recreated the Beatles to make Backbeat
item.description: ‘I knew people who said John Lennon was angry, insecure and cruel in the early days. When I met Ian Hart, I saw he could provide that’

item.title: Childminder married to Tory councillor pleads guilty to stirring up racial hatred
item.description: Lucy Connolly, of Northampton, told she faces substantial jail term over tweet calling for attacks on asylum hotels

item.title: A decade of decadence at Ahh Toots
item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->A decade of decadence at Ahh Toots<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: Did Starmer have to be so miserable? The doom and gloom may be more political than economic
item.description: The PM is managing expectations ahead of tough decisions in the budget in October.

item.title: Nasa astronaut reports ‘strange noise’ from Boeing Starliner spacecraft
item.description: Butch Wilmore reports pulsing sounds from capsule dogged with issues and set to return without astronauts

item.title: Further Details Emerge of Burial’s Soundtrack for New Harmony Korine Film ‘Baby Invasion’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> “I never actually met Burial and I never actually spoke to Burial,” the American filmmaker said just ahead of the movie’s premiere

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn to form alliance with four independent pro-Gaza MPs
item.description: Group calls for more MPs to join and vows to campaign on issues such as austerity and two-child benefit cap

item.title: Review: Forwards 2024 day two – ‘A near flawless day’
item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Review: Forwards 2024 day two – ‘A near flawless day’<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: Outstanding A Level results for boomsatsuma’s creative arts students
item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Outstanding A Level results for boomsatsuma’s creative arts students<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: Gaza: polio vaccination drive faces hurdles despite a pause in the conflict
item.description: Fighting in parts of Gaza has paused to allow young children to be vaccinated against polio.

item.title: Badminton School students celebrate stellar A Level results
item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Badminton School students celebrate stellar A Level results<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: Is there such a thing as an objectively beautiful building? Here’s the science
item.description: A beautiful building means that someone cared to do that little bit extra, which can be meaningful for its inhabitants.

item.title: I’ve read hundreds of diary entries to quantify the restorative power of Scotland’s lochs and rivers
item.description: Diary entries revealed people’s strong appreciation of Scotland’s freshwater environments.

item.title: Enjoyed Butter by Asako Yuzuki? Here are four more Japanese writers that explore misogyny through food
item.description: I invite you to sample four tasty literary courses that present, for your delectation, the trials and travails of post-war Japanese women.

item.title: ‘Tadpole water’ might sound gross – but it could be surprisingly good for your health
item.description: The latest TikTok wellness trend could be good for you but might prove difficult to swallow.

item.title: ‘Be more mushroom’ – Nine things we learnt at Shambala 2024
item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->‘Be more mushroom’ – Nine things we learnt at Shambala 2024<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: Man accused of enlisting strangers to rape drugged wife goes on trial in France
item.description: Dominique P, 71, being tried with 50 other men over alleged abuse of woman for years at couple’s Provence home

item.title: Listen: People Just Do Something – Fadumo Farah on Barton House, ACORN and a Holiday Inn mattress blockade
item.description: People Just Do Something is a relaxing and possibly enraging podcast about people who might self-identify as activists, untangling the means of effecting change in Bristol, broken Britain and beyond.

item.title: Seefeel – Everything Squared
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Seefeel

item.title: Lakeland Echoes: Wind, Rock, Fell, Rain & Sea Power’s Krankenhaus
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> In the latest edition of our new column, Luke Turner reflects on the connection between Sea Power and the music of the landscape that surrounds their Krankenhaus festival. Photos by Paul Hudson of Down At The Front except Esk pics by Luke Turner.

item.title: (Fish &) Chips On My Shoulder: Soft Cell Beside The Sea
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> In an exclusive extract from his new book, Bedsit Land, Patrick Clarke explores Soft Cell’s roots in English seaside tradition

item.title: tQ’s Exclusive Monthly Round-Up Playlist: August 2024
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Here’s everything we’ve covered at The Quietus this month, compiled for the listening pleasure of tQ’s subscribers

item.title: Music of the Month: The Best Albums and Tracks of August 2024
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> tQ’s staffers select the very finest new albums and tracks released this August, from Welsh-language goth brilliance to almighty dub

item.title: London Club Fabric Donates Exterior Sign to London Museum
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> The sign adorned the venue in 2019 to mark its 20th anniversary, and will form part of an exhibition celebrating “the meeting spots that bring London’s communities together”

item.title: Four breakthroughs that are changing our understanding of dreams
item.description: Researchers are developing theories about the purpose of dreams and learning why some people seem to be better at remembering them.

item.title: Healthy soils are good for your gut, brain and wellbeing – here’s why
item.description: From improving our gut microbiome to brain function, healthy and nutritious soil has lots of human health benefits.

item.title: The Last of Us and redemption: finding hope, light and God in the apocalyptic darkness
item.description: In his search for God in the apocalyptic world of a post-pandemic landscape, a theologian examines the idea of redemption in The Last of Us.

item.title: Five notorious cyberattacks that targeted governments
item.description: From disrupting nuclear facilities to throwing national health services into disarray, cyberattackers often target the most secure government computer systems.

item.title: Ryuichi Sakamoto’s ‘Coda’ Set for First International Release
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> The record, which is a solo piano version of his ‘Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence’ soundtrack, has never been available outside of Japan until now

item.title: tQ Subscriber Release: Nurse With Wound
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Steve Stapleton has been helming the surreal and riotous psychedelic industrial experimental unit NWW for 45 years now. John Doran and Russell Cuzner look at their new release available to only tQ subscribers today and examine what makes them special

item.title: Coco & Clair Clair: Girl review – girlish singsong with sizzle and spark
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Nice Girl World)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->After years of lightweight pop, the duo are breaking new ground with their second full-length album<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->

item.title: Orrin Evans and the Captain Black Big Band: Walk a Mile in My Shoe review – perseverance and Philly pride
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Imani Records)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->Evans’ soulful and communal album explores his health condition with the help of A-list instrumentalists and vocal stars including Bilal and the legendary Lisa Fischer

item.title: What We Do With What We Have: Björk’s Medúlla Turns 20
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Medúlla is arguably the point at which Björk turned from creating pop to a journey into the radically obscure, but in reality it is one of the most fully realised examples of an artist pushing the boundaries of what pop music can be and do, writes Matthew Barton

item.title: ‘I’m intrigued by failure’: Kim Deal on death, addiction – and releasing her debut solo album at 63
item.description: Having weathered the losses of close family members and collaborator Steve Albini – and supported Olivia Rodrigo live at her request – the Breeders and Pixies star finds herself mooting mortality and legacy

item.title: The Cable’s campaign succeeds: more than 50% increase in membership income and a £40k bonus
item.description: The support of our many new, and existing, members has seen the Cable pass the membership target we’ve been working towards for a year, a week ahead of the deadline.

item.title: Huw Montague Rendall: Contemplation album review – young opera star justifies the buzz
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Montague Rendall/Opéra Orchestre Normandie Rouen/Glassberg<!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Erato)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->The debut album from the British baritone lives up to the hype, showcasing his velvet and nuanced singing with room to spare

item.title: Jason Schwartzman: ‘I was the kid driving around all the record stores buying all the Oasis singles’
item.description: The actor answers your questions on auditioning for Wes Anderson, his love of Britpop, his telepathic mother and never hearing back from Ringo Starr

item.title: Jon Hopkins: Ritual review | Alexis Petridis’s album of the week
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Domino)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->Originally written for an installation with mind-altering intentions, the producer’s seventh album is occasionally engaging but dissolves into drift

item.title: Darkness, drama and Daft Punk: the Weeknd’s best songs – ranked!
item.description: Ahead of Abel Tesfaye’s livestreamed concert in Brazil to launch his new era, we rate his path from cult mixtape star to pop icon

item.title: ‘We need to face them on the streets’: how trade unions are responding to the far-right threat
item.description: The scale of the recent far-right turnout in Bristol rattled many trade unionists. Now, an anti-racist taskforce is forming to organise opposition in the South West, but activists say unions must show they have migrant workers’ backs.

item.title: Vladimir, vapes and defending democracy: when the Cable met Pussy Riot in BS3
item.description: Celebrating the subversive, we spent an evening with the legendary Russian dissidents to get behind the balaclavas to discuss all things protest.

item.title: Council still hounding people with bailiffs after ‘ethical’ approach promise
item.description: The Cable has uncovered evidence Bristol City Council is referring thousands of council tax debts to enforcement agencies despite a stated policy to do so only as a last resort.

item.title: ‘I’ve waited 25 years for this moment’: Oasis, the reunion – and what made them great
item.description: Their sneering vocals, seething guitars and thermonuclear charisma electrified the 90s. But will a reunion be a Champagne Supernova – or a Digsy’s Dinner? Our music writers weigh in

item.title: Will an Oasis reunion be a success? Definitely. Will it be worth it? Maybe | Alexis Petridis
item.description: Their first two albums and B-sides were fantastic, but after that things got bloated and weary. The reunion could go either way and that’s what makes it exciting

item.title: Education is the great liberator: the Bristol activists forging links with teachers in Palestine
item.description: Yasmeen Eshtaya is a Palestinian teacher whose life has been deeply affected by the brutal violence of the Israeli state. But she is committed to reconciliation and forming bonds through teaching Arabic – including to people in Bristol.

item.title: Under surveillance: how a man was recalled to prison after visiting a Bristol anarchist social centre
item.description: Toby Shone’s arrest by counter-terrorism police surveilling the BASE centre in Easton shows the state’s escalating clampdown on political dissent.

item.title: Fed up with the failings of mainstream media? Stand to be a Cable director
item.description: The Bristol Cable is looking for people to join our board of directors, who support and scrutinise the staff team’s work.

item.title: 2024 AGM: Help shape the Cable’s future and hear from inside our latest campaign to end Section 60
item.description: The Bristol Cable is not your average newspaper: we get together with members of the coop to plan ahead.

item.title: Listen: People Just Do Something and how to start a student encampment
item.description: People Just Do Something is a relaxing and possibly enraging podcast about people who might self-identify as activists, untangling the means of effecting change in Bristol, broken Britain and beyond.
